memberdef.argsstring: (double np1, uint64_t dt1, double np2, uint64_t dt2, std::vector< unsigned long long > &x_axis, std::vector< double > &corr, size_t n_bins)
memberdef.name: normalize_correlation

detaileddescription.para: This normalization applied to correlation curves that were calculated using a linear/logrithmic binning as described in

listitem.para: Fast calculation of fluorescence correlation data with asynchronous time-correlated single-photon counting, Michael Wahl, Ingo Gregor, Matthias Patting, Joerg Enderlein, Optics Express Vol. 11, No. 26, p. 3383

parameterdescription.para: The sum of the weights in the first correlation channel
The time difference between the first event and the last event in the first correlation channel
The sum of the weights in the second correlation channel
The time difference between the first event and the last event in the second correlation channel
The x-axis of the correlation
The array that contains the original correlation that is modified in place.
The number of bins per cascade of the correlation

memberdef.argsstring: (unsigned long long *t, unsigned int n_times, unsigned int *tac, unsigned int n_tac)
memberdef.name: make_fine_times

detaileddescription.para: Changes the time events by adding the micro time to the macro time

Changes the time events by adding the micro time to the macro time. The micro times should match the macro time, i.e., the length of the micro time array should be the at least the same length as the macro time array.

parameterdescription.para: An array containing the time events (macro times)
The number of macro times.
An array containing the micro times of the corresponding macro times
The number of micro time channels (TAC channels)

memberdef.argsstring: (size_t start_1, size_t end_1, size_t start_2, size_t end_2, size_t i_casc, size_t n_bins, std::vector< unsigned long long > &taus, std::vector< double > &corr, const unsigned long long *t1, const double *w1, size_t nt1, const unsigned long long *t2, const double *w2, size_t nt2)
memberdef.name: correlate

detaileddescription.para: Calculates the cross-correlation between two arrays containing time events.

Cross-correlates two weighted arrays of events using an approach that utilizes a linear spacing of the bins within a cascade and a logarithmic spacing of the cascades. The function works inplace on the input times, i.e, during the correlation the values of the input times and weights are changed to coarsen the times and weights for every correlation cascade.

The start position parameters
start_1
and
start_2
and the end position parameters
end_1
and
end_1
define which part of the time array of the first and second correlation channel are used for the correlation analysis.
The correlation algorithm combines approaches of the following papers:

listitem.para: Fast calculation of fluorescence correlation data with asynchronous time-correlated single-photon counting, Michael Wahl, Ingo Gregor, Matthias Patting, Joerg Enderlein, Optics Express Vol. 11, No. 26, p. 3383
Fast, flexible algorithm for calculating photon correlations, Ted A. Laurence, Samantha Fore, Thomas Huser, Optics Express Vol. 31 No. 6, p.829

parameterdescription.para: The start position on the time event array of the first channel.
The end position on the time event array of the first channel.
The start position on the time event array of the second channel.
The end position on the time event array of the second channel.
The number of the current cascade
The number of bins per cascase
A vector containing the correlation times of all cascades
A vector to that the correlation is written by the function
A vector of the time events of the first channel
A vector of weights for the time events of the first channel
The number of time events in the first channel
A vector of the time events of the second channel
A vector of weights for the time events of the second channel
The number of time events in the second channel

detaileddescription.para: This function coarsens a set of time events by dividing the times by two. In case two consecutive time events in the array have the same time, the weights of the two events are added to the following weight element and the value of the previous weight is set to zero.

parameterdescription.para: A vector of the time events of the first channel
A vector of weights for the time events of the first channel
The number of time events in the first channel
